title: Physics Concepts as Indicative Framework for Modelling Systems of Economy
text:
\[\begin{split} &
W = \partial A = \partial(E \cdot t) = \partial(p ⋅ r) = \partial\left( \frac{W}{v} ⋅ r \right)  \\&
\stackrel{Newtonian}{=} F \cdot r = mr \cdot a = I ⋅ \frac{v}{t} =  \frac{p}{t} ⋅ tv = Ft \cdot v =  pv = mv^2 \\&
\stackrel{Hamiltonian}{=} \mathcal{L} + \mathcal{H} = (E_{kin} - E_{pot}) + (E_{kin} + E_{pot}) = (\mathcal{K} - \mathcal{U}) + (\mathcal{K} + \mathcal{U}) = (\mathcal{K} - (\mathcal{V} + \mathcal{Z})) + (\mathcal{K} + \mathcal{U}) = (\mathcal{K} - \mathcal{U}) + E   \\&
\stackrel{ElectroMagnetic}{=}  \left( \frac{1}{2}mv^2 - q(\Phi - \vec{\mathcal{A}} \cdot \vec{v}) \right) + \left( \frac{1}{2} \frac{1}{m} (\vec{p} - q\vec{\mathcal{A}})^2 + q\Phi \right)   \\&
\stackrel{Relativistic}{=} \frac{v}{c} \sqrt{E^2 - (mc^2)^2}   \\&
\stackrel{Thermal}{=} ΔY + ΔH = PV = T \cdot V^{\frac{f+2}{f}} = T \cdot V^{(\frac{c_P}{c_V}-1)} = T \cdot V^{\kappa-1} = T \cdot N \cdot b_0 = T \cdot l \cdot g_0 = T \cdot m \cdot c_0    \\&
\stackrel{Quantistic}{=} ħ\mathcal{k} \cdot ω = ℎν\mathcal{k} = E\mathcal{k}    \\&
\end{split}\]












\(A =\) Action
\(E =\) total Energy
\(t =\) time


\(r =\) space
\(v =\) velocity
\(c =\) light speed


\(p =\) momentum
\(F =\) Force
\(I =\) Inertia


\(\mathcal{L} =\) Lagrangian
\(\mathcal{H} =\) Hamiltonian
\(\mathcal{K} =\) kinetic Energy


\(\mathcal{U} =\) effective potential Energy
\(\mathcal{V} =\) potential Energy
\(\mathcal{Z} = \frac{1}{2}\frac{L_0^2}{mr^2}\) Centrifugal Potential


\(V =\) Volume
\(\mathcal{k} =\) Wave Vector (“curvature”)
\(W =\) Work


\(P =\) Pressure
\(L_0 =\) angular momentum
\(T =\) endogen Temperature


\(H =\) exogen Heat
\(Y =\) endogen Energy (Potential)
\(\Phi =\) Electric Potential


\(\mathcal{A} =\) Magnetic Potential
\(b_0 =\) Boltzmann constant
\(g_0 =\) Gas constant


\(q =\) charge
\({\epsilon}_0 =\) electric constant
\({\mu}_0 =\) magnetic constant


\(\mathcal{E} =\) Electric Field
\(\mathcal{B} =\) Magnetic Field
\(N =\) amount of particles


H\(\mathcal{C} =\) heat capacity
\(c_0 =\) specific heat
…


…
\(l =\) Moll quantity
…


\(\kappa = \frac{c_P}{c_V} = \frac{f+2}{f}\)
…
\(f =\) degrees fo freedom


…
…
…






References [1]:




References

1. Eckhard R (2006) Theoretische Physik: Mechanik, 1st ed. Springer Spektrum Akademischer Verlag


2. Cockshott WP (2011) Classical Econophysics. Routledge Advances in Experimental; Computable Economics

text:
Energy [1]:
\[
\begin{split}
&
E = \overline{W} = E_{trl} + E_{rot} + E_{vbr} + E_{spn} + ... + E_{mix} =  
E_{kin} + E_{pot} =
E_{Magn} + E_{Elec}
\\
&
\stackrel{continuum}{=}
\frac{1}{2} kT + \frac{1}{2} kT  =
kT
\\
&
\stackrel{quantum}{=}
\hbar\omega =
h\nu
\stackrel{distribtion}{=}
h\nu \frac{1}{e^{\frac{h\nu}{kT}}-1}
\\
&
\stackrel{relativistic}{=}
\sqrt{ (pc)^2 + (mc^2)^2 } =
c \cdot \sqrt{ p^2 + (mc)^2 }
\end{split}
\tag{1}\]
\[
E_{kin}^{max} =
eV_0 =
h(\nu - \nu_0)
\tag{2}\]
Average Energy Densitiy (Electromagnetic Intensity and Poynting-Vector): 
\[
\langle $w$_{EM} \rangle =
\frac{1}{2} \varepsilon_0 (\mathscr{E}^2 + c^2 \mathscr{B}^2 ) =
\varepsilon_0 \mathscr{E}^2 + \frac{1}{\mu_0}\mathscr{B}^2 =
\frac{1}{c} \frac{\mathscr{E \cdot B}}{\mu_0} =
\frac{1}{c} \mathscr{I} =
\frac{1}{c} \langle |\vec{S}| \rangle \tag{3}\]
Quest: What is momentum \(p\) if there is no mass, \(m=0\) ?
Quest: Is energy \(E\) also the cause for mass \(m\), apart from being the ability to do work \(W\), \(\Delta E = W = F \cdot x = m \cdot a \cdot x = mx \cdot \frac{dv}{dt} = mx \cdot \frac{d^2x}{dt^2} = M \cdot \frac{d^2x}{dt^2}\) ?
